item.title: Are Desktops going extinct?
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

i believe the answer to the question is yes for the most part it will be extinct. maybe not as fast as the article says but in 10 years i see hardly any desktops anyway except the (few) ppl that well want to keep using their desktops. even if its not in 10 years, in time they will be i say 50 years would be a max. I really doubt my grandchildren will know what a desktop pc is unless they have visited a technology museum. I like the mobility laptops give me compared to desktops. can you lie on the couch while you play on your desktop? sure if you have wireless mouse and keyboard but is the screen going to be a little bit harder to see? probably. can you take your desktop anywhere you want easily and play games where ever you want? not as easy a with a laptop. sure it may cost more for a laptop that is as powerful as a cheaper desktop but there are many perks that you are paying for but you are also paying(figuratively) b/c laptops arent as customizable as desktops… thats the only downside i see to mobile devices is i cant take them apart and upgrade parts and stuff.

exhibit 1: http://www.ubuntu.com/devices

2: http://www.usb.org/developers/onthego or bt keyboard and mouse

3: micro hdmi/hdmi adapter/WiDi

4: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tegra#Upcoming_releases there is a picture graph somewhere(http://images.anandtech.com/reviews/SoC/NVIDIA/Kal-El/roadmap.jpg) on the net that shows the predicted increase in power that the tegra series will achieve. also other mobile gpu’s will increase in performance to keep up. I heard that there are gpus better than the tegra 3 out so it shows how well the competitors are doing. Intel is also in the mobile device market now.

you are all not thinking outside the box. i mean top-end cell phones have 1.2ghz/1.4ghz quad-cores, and 1.5ghz dual-cores with 1-2 GB of ram. With cloud storage who needs TB’s of storage. plus with usb on the go you can increase the possible storage capacities. These phones have vastly increasing in power over the past couple of years. How powerful were computers 10 years ago? not much more powerful than todays high-end smartphones(http://www.computerhope.com/history/2000.htm). The next 10 years wireless technologies will vastly increase in speed and availability.

I think i can stop i have probably wrote enough.

Read full topic

item.title: Are Desktops going extinct?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Frell:

silab have you seen that liquid that computers can be submerged into that has a low boiling point or whatever? spel knows alot about it

I’m sure you mean mineral oil, and the only reason it’s used is because it’s relatively available and because it isn’t conductive, you can use vegetable oil instead however it spoils relatively quickly

Read full topic

Sorry, but I don’t want to play Minecraft, Terraria, Stronghold, or Runescape on a fucking cellular phone.

Like I said, the towers are probably the only thing that will probably go obsolete. Technology is all about developing something that’s small and fast… like Asians.

item.title: Are Desktops going extinct?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Working for my isp, a small part of my job is installing internet for customers who have opted for a technician to hook up the modem, rather than receive it by mail. I usually get 2-3 of these orders each day, which I save for the end of the day because they are easy.

and since I started over a year ago, I’ve installed internet to maybe 3-4 desktop computers and they were those all-in-one pc’s . EVERYONE has laptops now and I don’t see people usng desktops at all.

They won’t go extinct but their popularity has greatly declined and will continue to decline.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Frell wrote:

m1lkman:

From what I am hearing, desktops won’t disappear in the next couple of years but as technology advances they will diminish. Yes, desktops are going extinct.

item.title: Are Desktops going extinct?
item.dc:creator: @dawgsays123 dawgsays123
item.description:
@dawgsays123 wrote:

[quote=“m1lkman, post:10, topic:448650”][quote author=dawgsays123 link=topic=551545.msg4041355#msg4041355 date=1341674832]
No. Whoever wrote that article has no idea what [size=24pt][font=arial black]SHE’S[/font][/size] talking about. They are still making new desktop processor technologies and they won’t stop to let smartphones take over. you can’t play crysis 3 on a smartphone.
[/quote]

But you can play Crysis 3 on a laptop.[/quote]

Yeah I guess, but the price of buying a laptop that could play crysis 3 compared to building a desktop that can play crysis 3 Would be night and day. you could spend 700-800 dollars on a desktop that can play crysis 3 and over 1K on a laptop that can.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Gamers will kindly switch to a laptop so long as they are still fully modular (and cooling is no longer an issue) and can be hooked to a bigger monitor at home.

item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

I personally think Desktops will be gone.

Gaming rigs and server towers are the only things that will survive. Everything else is getting thinner and sleeker. When was the last time you saw a commercial for a new Desktop?
